name: iris-hollandica
country-or-region-of-origin: Hybrid of species from Spain and Morocco
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
flower-description: 1-several flowers at the top of a naked stem, 6-parted with 3 outer, spreading or pendent "falls" and 3 inner, erect "standards", variously colored.  Blooms in mid to late spring (April/May)
leaf-description: Strap-like, overlapping at base, oriented in one plane
poison-symptoms: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR, OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.  Nausea, salivation, vomiting, abdominal pain, lethargy, diarrhea, elevated temperature following ingestion; skin irritation upon contact with seeds, rootstock, or cell sap.
poison-toxic-principle: Pentacylic terpenoids (zeorin, missourin and missouriensin), Irisin, iridin, or irisine
